<u>Connections of the Corpus Callosum with the 
posterior third of the Brain <\u>.
The corpus callosum in the posterior third of the 
brain has a much simpler arrangement than 
in either the anterior or middle third. The fibres 
appear to be derived from the whole of this region 
back to the extreme tip of the occipital lobe.
Coming from the occipital lobe there are two 
sets of fibres: the one is callosal and the other 
is made up of the special bundles wh: are 
sometimes collectively known as “Gratiolet’s optic 
radiations” or “optic expansion “. The two sets of fibres 
are perfectly distinct. <s>The “optic expansion is confined <\s>
The callosal fibres, as a general statement, line the 
posterior horn of the ventricle forming what was 
known to the older anatomists as the “tapetum “,
while the “optic expansion “ lies outside of this confined 
to an area as sharply defined as if it had been 
actually drawn artificially upon the preparation. The callosal fibres 
are derived from the convolutions in the postero-parietal 
and occipital regions. They pass obliquely forwards & inwards 
through the “optic expansion “ area until the come 
to lie in contact with the ependyma of the posterior 
horn. They afterwards pass forwards cross in the 
<u>splenium corpus callosi <\u>, and become almost entirely if not completely attached to 
the <s>thalamus I chr of <\s> posterior extremity of the 
thalamus of the opposite side. In this course they
